titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for Helen C. Bower papers, 1865-1959.
titlestmt.author: Justin Lee Tyler

repository.corpname: Detroit Public Library. Burton Historical Collection.

did.abstract: Detroit Free Press Film Critic Helen Bower's papers contain much movie and entertainment memorabilia, as well as personal papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Helen Carolyn Bower was born in Michigan on January 7, 1896, to D. Herbert and Amelia Bower. She came from a newspaper family: her father owned and edited the Buchanan (Mich.) Record, and her grandfather, Daniel Bower, had owned a newspaper in Williamsport, Penn. before the Civil War. By 1910, the family was living in Detroit, Mich. After graduating from high school Bower got a job at the Detroit Free Press in 1914, covering women's clubs. She left the paper to attend the University of Michigan, but returned in 1916 to become Assistant Society Editor. Her father was killed in that same year in an automobile accident. Though Helen had announced her engagement in 1918 to U.S. Army Lieutenant Daniel W. Kent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence D. Kent of Buchanan, they were never married. The 1920 Federal Census shows Daniel Kent, age 24, living in Buchanan with his parents, working as an office clerk. Helen was active in a number of organizations and served on the board of Women's Hospital, Women's City Club, Friends of the Detroit Public Library, and two sororities. She worked for the National War Work Council Overseas Service during World War I, and spent time in 1922 Japan and other Far East countries.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research use.

otherfindaid.head: Other finding aids note
otherfindaid.p: Finding aid available in the Burton Historical Collection.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

controlaccess.subject: Women -- Societies and clubs -- Michigan -- Detroit.

dsc.head: Container List
dsc.p: The following section contains a detailed listing of the materials in the collection.

did.unittitle: Condolences received on death of her mother, 1947

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contained in this series are biographical information and materials, correspondence and organizations with which Helen Bower was involved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Among the correspondents are G. Mennen Williams (Note Cards, Box 6:5) and Christmas cards from Kim Novak, Torn Patterson (founder of the Stratford Festival) and Gregory Peck (Box 5:8). There are also many letters written to servicemen during World War 1 (Box 2) and World War II (Box 4).

did.unittitle: Greeting Cards, Notes and Note Cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Helen Bower kept two types of diaries. One was a day-book account, which are contained in small hooks in Boxes 7 and 8. The others were kept in loose-leaf binders which also served as scrapbooks. Most of the material in these larger diaries were left loose, between pages. These items have been removed and are located in Boxes 8-15, with the appropriate headings. The diaries themselves are listed under "Volumes". Among the material from the diaries are correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs and theater programs. Notable autographs include those of Mary Pickford (Box 9:9); Edgar A. Guest (Box 12:5; 13:1; 15:3), photos of Eleanor Roosevelt (11:4) and Rosalind Russell (15:6).

did.unittitle: Folder 1â€”Sympathy Cards/Guest Book for Mrs. Amelia Bower

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When Helen Bower attended the University of Michigan in 1916, she had already started working at the Detroit Free Press. The daughter and granddaughter of newspapermen, Helen had journalism in her veins. This section includes a number of her articles and newspaper columns, dating from the 1920's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Helen was a member of many organizations, and served on the board of directors for several of them, including Friends of the Detroit Public Library, Women's City Club, Kappa Kappa Gamma and Theta Sigma Phi sororities. She was also active in the Lutheran church and served as editor for many organizational publications.

did.unittitle: Friends of the Detroit Public Library, 1942-1963
St. Peter's Danish Evangelical Lutheran Church, 1956-1963
"The Friendly Wee Press"/"The Friendly Little Free Press", 1953-1963
"The Nader Star": Official George Nader Fan Club, 1954

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As movie critic for the Detroit Free Press for fifteen years, Helen Bower accumulated a vast amount of material on the topic, from movie magazines to press kits, theater programs to movie scripts. Helen even made an appearance in a major film, "Teacher's Pet", starring Clark Gable. Correspondence (Box 21:6) includes autographs of Jerry Lewis, Tom Patterson and Agnes Moorehead.

did.unittitle: Sub-series A: Press Kits and Releases
Press Kits--"Around the World in 80 Days", 1956
Walt Disney/"Darby O'Gill and the Little People", 1958-1959
Detroit Town Hall, 1947-1951; Detroit Opera Theatre, 1961-1962/ Detroit Symphony Orchestra, 1962-1963
"Centro internazionale delle arti e del costume", 1951
"The Journal of the Screen Producers Guild", 1956-1960
"A Flag is Born", by Ben Hecht
"Porgy and Bess", Sammy Davis Jr. and Carmen McRae Raymond Ladouceur
Spike Jones and his City Slickers
Diaries, 1926-1952 (1948 and 1952 had only loose items; no written pages)
Detroit Free Press Front Page: "We've Got the Right Bower!", February 28, 1958
Membership Certificate, The Order of Dames of the Loyal Legion, to Helen Carolyn Bower, 1915
Portfolio of Impressions of "Pork Chop Hill" by Howard Brodie
